snippet: Profitable American companies enjoyed a 12.6 percent tax rate, far below the federal statutory rate, thanks to legal loopholes, according to the Government Accountability Office.
abstract: Government Accountability Office releases study showing that biggest, most profitable American companies pay only a fraction of taxes they would owe under official corporate rate; finds that legal loopholes allow large corporations to enjoy 12.6 percent tax rate, far below federal statutory rate of 35 percent.

headline.main: Big Companies Paid a Fraction of Corporate Tax Rate
headline.print_headline: Big Companies Paid a Fraction of Corporate Tax Rate

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include YouTube videos showing what your computer would look like if it were infected with various viruses, and Telefóni...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include YouTube videos showing what your computer would look like if it were infected with various viruses, and Telefónica to start selling a smartphone in Spain that runs on the Firefox mobile operating system.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Firefox Smartphone, and Virus Collector

snippet: Mr. Peanut, the symbol of the Planters brand since 1916, is getting a new voice to help sell a new product line. Bill Hader takes over for Robert Downey Jr.

headline.main: Look Who’s Talking for Mr. Peanut Now

snippet: The disclosure last month of the covert Prism program has drawn criticism from privacy officials and activists in Britain, Germany and France, but it has hardly been a roar.

headline.main: E.U. Reaction to Data Sharing Revelations Grew Slowly
headline.print_headline: E.U. Reaction to Data Sharing Revelations Grew Slowly
